title: 112_s2283
content: Tribal requests for a major disaster or emergency declaration under the Stafford Act. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to allow Indian tribal governments to request a major disaster declaration from the President. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to allow Indian tribal governments to request a major disaster declaration from the President. Indian tribal governments can receive assistance through a declaration made by the President at the request of a State if no declaration is made for the same incident. Cost share adjustments for Indian tribal governments can be adjusted or waived according to criteria established by the President. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to allow Indian tribal governments to request an emergency declaration from the President. The Chief Executive of an affected Indian tribal government can submit a request for an emergency declaration, with cost share adjustments being possible according to criteria set by the President. The amendment to the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief Act allows Indian tribal governments to request emergency declarations from the President. Cost share adjustments for non-Federal contributions by Indian tribal governments can be made based on criteria set by the President. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief Act is amended to include a definition of Indian tribal government as recognized by the Secretary of the Interior under the Federally Recognized Indian Tribe List Act of 1994. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief Act is amended to define the term 'Chief Executive' as the recognized administrative officer of an Indian tribal government. The President will consider unique conditions affecting federally recognized Indian tribes when promulgating necessary regulations for this section. Additionally, a reference to this amendment is added after section 102 of the Act. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief Act is amended to include Indian tribal governments and officials in references to 'State and local' governments.
